title: Intentionally Random
text:
p5 ellipse()




Try it yourself: LINK 3 in Google Doc

Press play button to run sketch. Try directions to the right.




What happens if we change 
ellipse(200, 200, 100) to  ellipse(300, 200, 100)  ?

title: Intentionally Random
text:
p5 Randomness
 From there, what happens if we change 
ellipse(300, 200, 100) to  ellipse(random(300), 200, 100) ?  Be careful to match the text exactly! Try running several times.

title: Intentionally Random
text:
random() with one argument




Try it yourself: LINK 4 in Google Doc

Press play button to run sketch. Try directions to the right.




What happens if we change 
random(300) to  random(10)  ?

title: Intentionally Random
text:
random() with two arguments

From there, what happens if we change  
random(10) to  random(10, 20) 
?

Where else does random() appear?

title: Intentionally Random
section: How does human intention guide each of these examples?
text: How does human intention guide each of these examples?

title: Intentionally Random
text:
Jean Arp





Jean (Hans) Arp, Untitled (Collage with Squares Arranged according to the Law of Chance), 1916–17




While chance was undoubtedly the point of departure for this and other works in the series According to the Laws of Chance, the relatively ordered appearance of Arp’s collages suggest he did not fully relinquish control.

source: moma.org

text: Functions and Arguments

title: Intentionally Random
text:
random() and ellipse()
random(10) // one argument, returns a number between 0 and 10

ellipse(200, 200, 100, 100) // four arguments, x, y, width, height
